element_texts.text: Completed

HEDGEROW THEATRE MOYLAN-ROSE VALLEY, PA. 
Monday, Dec. 6.
Dear Sherwood,
Next Sunday our vacation begins, and I hope it includes at least one day in New York with you and Eleanor. When do you have to start to Va.? If I come over on Sunday will you be free? Jax? + I are planning to be there on Monday + Tuesday for several errands, when maybe we can all get together at night, but he may have to do a visit by himself on Sunday. I'd like to be with you on Sunday if it's o.k. Will you be at Mary's? I hoped you were coming over again, but I've had my nose in the typewriter so much and my ear on the
Completed

telephone that I'm hardly fit for humming?. You'll have to show me.
Mims?. (Philips)?
Completed

HEDGEROW THEATRE
MOYLAN-ROSE VALLEY, PA.
June 2, after "Candida"
Well, Sherwood, my love,
So you're not coming up? Letty told me of your letter to her, and I had just written one to Eleanor in N.Y., thinking she was still there. I suppose it will be forwarded to her. We did want you to see "The Frodi"?, but it will still be running in the fall, I'm sure, and maybe you can see it then if you don't catch it some time in the summer when you feel the urge to come, willy-nilly. The schedule until the end of the Shaw? Festival doesn't give me enough days off to make the trip to Rifshin?, or I'd be planning the trip there. If the next new play after "Simpleton" doesn't have me in it maybe I can do it in mid-August, but what's the use of talking about it? I can't have all this acting + holidays as well. 
Have you seen or heard from the Feiblemans? at all? I wrote one letter to Dorothy quite a while ago, after a long interval, and I don't know whether she's given up the idea of coming here this summer. I suppose
Completed

she has, since she hasn't mentioned it. I liked them so much and hoped they would be around.
Lou? + that dentist finished with you yet? I suppose you'll be so beautiful with a new jaw when we see you again that all the women will fall in love with you twice off-crossed out over! 
I had a wonderful time with Jax? the other night. We went to the Mn? with Adrienne and Peter and then to their house. Adrienne and Peter went to bed and left us to ourselves, + it was the first time we've had a chance to talk to each other in weeks. At least he was able to talk to me as he never has before. He'd been living in the theatre alone + kind of sick of people. I didn't bother him because I knew he'd find me if he wanted me. We saw the day come and grow, and it was a full day for Jax?, from 930 on. He carried on the afternoon meeting with disfath? + vitality and humor such as took my breath away. It was like watching the "bravest of the brave" in a tournament that crossed out never existed in the middle ages.
Completed

-2-
Who's coming to be with you this summer? And have you already moved to Ripshin?
The smart-alec "know nothings" of newspaper men on the Phila. sheets? didn't dare to like a new runs? like "the Frodi", by Sidney Whipple of the N.Y. World-Telegram, who came for dinner (and who I think is an awful bore) wrote a little more intelligently about the show. He was obviously impressed by the place. But the talk in + by the audience itself is enough for the life of the play. We got several letters, among them one strong one from the Women's International League for Peace + Freedom, and they are recommending the show. It will be as much talked about as "Tragedy".
What are you writing now that you don't even get .01 a word for? Suppose Kipling did get $1.25 a word? What of it? I'd rather read Kit Brandon than Kipling. By the way, didn't the movies want to buy "Kit Brandon"? What's the matter with unclear your publishers? I think that book would make a wonderful movie, but maybe I'm all wet.  Is the subject matter beyond their daring?
Completed

Well if you get a chance to come suddenly, send a wire + we'll be around. I don't want to be off somewhere else when you're coming.
Heaps of love,
Mims
And good luck to John + his spouse!
Completed

Hedgerow
H.W. Wagner Manager C.V. Mierley Treasurer; Official AAA Hotel; Hotel Huntingdon Route 22 Phone 830; Huntingdon, PA. -- Letterhead
March 14.
Dear Sherwood,
Since the December vacation I've been wanting to write to you, and every time we've gone off on one of these tours I've expected to get a letter to you. They can haul out the whiskey bottles next door to me if they want to, but I'm writing a letter to Sherwood.
Mexico City always sounds so good. I hope you are finding it so. Can't you hunt up a theatre there for us so we can winter there?
Hotel Lewistown under same management -- Letterhead
Completed

Jax? showed me your note with the copy of the letter you wrote about the "Winesburg" complications. It's pretty sickening, all night, so we won't do anything to make the situation more complicated, even tho we want to bring the play back into the repertory.
Right now we have no repertory going, because we haven't had a theatre to play in since December 5. The new addition to the stage is finished, and the new side prosceniums are beautiful. But all the electrical equipment had to be ripped out for the job, and
Completed

2
H.W. Wagner Manager; C.V. Mierley Treasurer; Official AAA Hotel; Hotel Huntingdon; Route 22 Phone 830; Huntingdon, PA. -- Letterhead
now the big work is to reinstall the wiring and the lamps, and it has taken longer than we knew. When we broke up at Christmas time we said we would set no reopening date until we saw the completion of the job -- that no pressure would be brought to get opened again. We kept saying, on the telephone (and there have been an encouraging quantity of calls) "after the first of the month". Well, January passed and the work seemed only started; February
Hotel Lewistown under same management -- Letterhead
Completed

has gone. So we began to think we'd better consider the situation and examine the possibilities. We have a new play that we're longing to do -- the peace play called "The Frodi". The rights to that are now clear for us. Also, there is April 21, our birthday, and we'll be 15 years old this time.  Also, our funds were running low and how were we going to eat if we didn't plan the income? So, after a compelling speech by Harry Sheppard -- (you know that superabundant vitality and "there's magic in the night when the heart is young") -- we sat and thought and discussed from 6:30 to 12 last Monday night
Completed

3
H.W. Wagner Manager; C.V. Mierley Treasurer; Official AAA Hotel; Hotel Huntingdon; Route 22 Phone 830; Huntingdon; PA. -- Letterhead
and from 930 AM until 4 PM Tuesday, until we had set our reopening date for April 9th. We knew we were leaving Thursday morning for this present tour -- Lebanon and Mansfield before Huntingdon -- and that by the time we got back we'd be that much further away from a plan. It was a great meeting. It called for exercise of patience as well as painstaking reason and mathematical figuring, and we really got something done in the way of group thinking, 
Hotel Lewistown under same management--Letterhead
Completed

with a masterful chairmanship job from Jap?. He's still introducing some of us to each other and teaching us how to speak to each other. Who else would take the trouble to do it, or could understand the necessity. And it's that same necessity that tears him up. 
Well, we know we can't have a new production for April 21, but we are going to play "Candida" that night. It was the first performance at Hedgerow on April 21, 1923, so it's in for the 15th year, altho with a different cast. The show is really awfully good
Completed

4
H.W. Wagner Manager; C.V. Mierley Treasurer; Official AAA Hotel; Hotel Huntingdon; Route 22 Phone 830; Huntingdon, PA. -- Letterhead
now. And all 6 people are old-timers -- Jap?, Ferd (Lehy?), David, Harry, Kate (Prossy?) and myself. We just played it at Lebanon Valley College and at Mansfield State Teachers College. Tonight we give Twelfth Night at Juniata College in this town. 
Well, I hope you are planning to be with us in April -- certainly for April 21. If we have any kind of a party at all I think it's going to be just us. We discourage the entertainment
Hotel Lewistown under same management--Letterhead
Completed

of the press, etc. on such occasions now that we don't have Hanley?. Yes, we've had another "purge: in which we killed off Ferril?, Graham, Young, Hanley?, and Laura Freund. We were kind of strapped for labor for a while, but the atmosphere was so much clearer. Joe Taulane? is with us most of the week -- he goes over to N.Y. once a week for a while and he's on this trip with us. Letty is with us and seems happy and easy -- I really haven't had a chance to talk to her since she joined us.
We got the big house on the hill, where we now have
Completed

5
H.W. Wagner Manager; C.V. Mierley Treasurer; Official AAA Hotel; Hotel Huntingdon; Route 22 Phone 830; Huntingdon, PA. -- Letterhead
our meals, and eventually we hope to make more of a home for ourselves out of the old place, where some of us still live.
I've been just bursting with things to say to you, and now that I've started I don't seem to be able to write them. I want a whole long afternoon or a whole night to talk to you, and don't put it off too long.
In the face of what's happening in the world, running theatres must seem kind of unimportant, but I can still see a relation.
Hotel Lewistown under same management -- Letterhead
Completed

Is Eleanor with you, or did she have to stay in this part of the world? And Harry told me that Mary Eunnett? passed thru Rose Valley on her way to join up with you. Is she along?
What are you doing, anyhow, and write me a letter if you feel like it. I'll write again when I can. 
For weeks I was living under a kind of cloud, but just a few weeks I think I was born again, and now I feel as tho I know nothing and can begin to learn all over.
My love to you.
Mims
Completed

Thurs. before the show
Dear Sherwood,
I was bothered because I hadn't written you, and today came your letter.  The days from 10 AM on are pretty full, but I might have got a letter off to you some night after a show instead of going and staying out all night with the boys! I'm afraid I was meant to be a slut, and every once in a while it breaks thru ----- when there is opportunity ---- you know "the time, the place, and the girl".  I said at the beginning of the season that now we have a method of working I could be a butterfly, + I think I've lived up to it pretty well. But I still feel the summer was incomplete without that visit to Ripshin.
Completed

2
Joe + I kept looking at the schedule + plotting occasionally, but it never worked out. Now I have another idea, but I whispered in Mary's ear this evening + looked at the schedule. After the performance of "St. Jean?" on the 17th, Jap, Mary, + I are loose from performances, + it depends on the replacement rehearsals necessary between then and the night of the 22nd as to whether we can get away for that long. I think Adrienne would lend us her car, + Mary could drive. I'll find out tonight, if I can, whether we can risk it. That's the only chance I see, + I'm crazy to do it. 
Mark Anthony never came at all, but Dorothy was here for 5 days, in early July. She is a grand person + I don't know when I've met somebody who on such short acquaintance I felt really "got" us. There are some people who you know are your friends at once, and I felt that about her -- and Jimmy, too. She had to go N.Y. and on their way back to N. Orleans they both stopped here for a day. From our conversation with her, I don't think the Hedgerow in New Orleans is imminent for this
Completed

3
winter, but she is setting the stage well and slowly for a possible season down there in another year. I had a letter from her the other day, saying that she and Muriel Francis were interviewing some newspaper men on the idea + she is sending a full description of the plant and equipment. 
She doesn't feel that she could underwrite the whole project and at this stage it seems doubtful as to whether she could get enough backing for us to make it possible this winter. And I
Completed

4
don't think it's wise at this point for us to consider splitting the co this January for the purpose of taking only part of it down there.
Sunday.
Well, that's as far as I got.
Letty landed yesterday at dinner looking fit as a fiddle and with samples of things she had done, also news of you. I don't know whether that visit to you will come off or not. I've mentioned it to Jap, and he knows he can make it by train, since one person driving all that distance for such a short time doesn't seem so good, and even if he would go alone it would be swell, because he really needs it. He's been doing the most intensive kind of teaching during the past few weeks, and as long as he is on the lot it doesn't stop, because even outside of the appointments, if we only get together for a drink at somebody's house, it goes right on as long as there are people who want to know. And it's right that it should be so -- because that's the kind of teacher he is -- but it's wearing him out, and he ought to get off the lot for a few days where he won't be exposed to the continual unendingness of it, so that he can come back fresh and carry on some more. But if I say two words too much he won't go. Of course I want to come, too, but I'd rather have him go alone than not at all. So why don't you make him come? Letty said that she thought you were coming up on the first of October, so maybe he'll think it's too close to that. I may be just talking thru my hat anyhow.
Joe went back to N.Y. on the 15th August, but he's been coming over weekends. He's around today working on automobiles with Paul and Arthur Rich.
Completed

Dining Room Service
Herbert T. Flock Prop.
The Mansfield Hotel Mansfield, PA.
March 16
Dear Sherwood,
You must not get ill any more. A great, strapping guy like you, and you have to go and get influenza. You must have had a hell of a winter. Here we are, tromping? again. Tonight we play in the State Teachers College in this town "Beyond the Horizon." They have had only music and some kind of very cheap dramatic stuff before, and we are an experiement in "revisions? " Theatre. So if they like us and if they get the
